column3:
This is a {{c1::cloze}} deletion test. You can have several {{c2::clozes}} on the same card. In the pdf preview, they get displayed in different colours.

You can also define a {{c3::cloze with a hint::hint}}.
column4: You can display some additional info on the back of the card.

column3: A preimage of an element \(b \in B\) under a map \(f\colon A\to B\) is {{c1::an element \(a\in A\) with \(f(a) = b\).::(think of an element in \(A\))}}

LaTeX tabulars get converted to html tables: {{c1::

\(a\)

\(b\)

\(c\)

\(d\)

}}

Aligned equations that contain cloze deletions are best simulated using tabulars:
  

{{c1:: \(f(\vec v_1, \dots , \vec v_{i-1}, \vec v_i + \vec v_i' , \vec v_{i+1},\dots , \vec v_n)\) }}

  

\(=\) {{c2:: \(\begin{aligned} & f(\vec v_1, \dots , \vec v_{i-1}, \quad \vec v_i\quad , \vec v_{i+1},\dots , \vec v_n) \\ +\, & f(\vec v_1, \dots , \vec v_{i-1}, \quad \vec v_i’\quad , \vec v_{i+1},\dots , \vec v_n) \end{aligned}\) }}

 

  

{{c3:: \(f(\vec v_1, \dots , \vec v_{i-1}, s\vec v_i , \vec v_{i+1},\dots , \vec v_n)\) }}

 

=

{{c4:: \(s \cdot f(\vec v_1, \dots , \vec v_{i-1}, \phantom{s} \vec v_i, \vec v_{i+1},\dots , \vec v_n)\) }}
